children.subject: Thank you! Do you think taking 127 without 110 before would be a bad idea? (I have only had 54 for linear algebra and the small amount that was covered in DS 100)

Hmm that's a tricky question. 

The requirements for 127 are only ee16a/b (not 110), but having not taken ee16a/b myself, I don't know how much more the two ee courses cover than 54. 

For me, I am not sure if I would have been comfortable with just 54 because my semester of 54 was very computational, and 127 deals with more proof-based linear algebra. 

E.g. Less "Compute the determinant of this matrix" and more "Prove that if $$A,B$$ PSD matrices, then $$\langle A, B \rangle \geq 0$$". (my hw problem over break hehe)

If you feel comfortable with proof based techniques then 110 might not be needed ,

The first third of 127 is mostly linear algebra , but I found that it assumed you were already at the level of proofing. 

I have friends in the course right now who have only taken 54 and they find it somewhat manageable if hard. 

In this semester, we also had a diagnostic quiz on the 2nd lecture, and you can try enrolling in both 110 + 127 and if you take the quiz and don't feel comfortable, you can drop 127 till a later semester.

Math 110 highly recommend as a course. 

It may be less applicable for some data science aspects but if you want to take Stat154 or Stat151a (linear modeling core statistics course) it may be useful. It's also recommended for statistics graduate school. 

A lot of upper div stats/modeling is linear algebra, and Math110 gives you a good rigourous mathematical understanding of linear algebra. 

I enjoyed it because 

- It's required for a bunch of my classes and grad school 

- It was a nice transition from computational heavy lower div courses to abstract proof based upper division courses (Ive found it very helpful in 127 and 189 this semester). 

- Sug Woo Shin in Fa18 was an amazing professor if you can take it with him

- I really like linear algebra so it was fun to learn more. 

If you are interested in the Stats/business analytics you might want to check out Stat153: Time series though I have not taken it myself yet.

history.content: I am a sophomore in EECS who will have finished 188 and 61c after this semester and wondering what the best cs class for me to take next semester would be? I am currently considering 170 and think 186 (databases) would be useful, though I don't really want to take it since it's an online lecture course. What have people found to be the most useful and enjoyable UD cs classes? Also, I really like statistics and math so any suggestions for best math classes for data analytics type stuff would be really helpful! (110 or stat 154?) Thank you!!
history.subject: most useful classes for EECS w/ data science interest?
